title: Creates a Radiology Insights job with the given request body.

content.value:
[**2143-4-13**] 5:04 PM
CT ABD W&W/O C; CT CHEST W&W/O C                                Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 38350**]
CT PELVIS W&W/O C
Reason: ? PE, evidence of pneumonia
Admitting Diagnosis: SEPSIS
Field of view: 38 Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
______________________________________________________________________________
[**Hospital 4**] MEDICAL CONDITION:
52 year old man with urosepsis, s/p nephrostogram on [**4-12**], today with acute
SOB, fever, rigors.
REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION:
? PE, evidence of pneumonia
No contraindications for IV contrast
______________________________________________________________________________
FINAL REPORT
INDICATION:  History of urosepsis status post nephrostogram on [**4-12**], today
with acute shortness of breath, fevers, and rigors.  Also reported hematocrit
drop.  Evaluate for pulmonary embolism or hematoma.
COMPARISON:  Non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis dated [**2143-4-11**].
TECHNIQUE:  MDCT acquired images of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis were
obtained before and after the administration of IV contrast.  A true CT
angiogram could not be performed due to lack of appropriate intravenous
access.
CT OF THE CHEST WITHOUT AND WITH IV CONTRAST:  Evaluation of the pulmonary
arteries is limited with no large central pulmonary embolism seen.  Evaluation
of the segmental and subsegmental branches is limited.  There is a central
venous catheter that terminates in the right atrium.  There are numerous small
mesenteric and axillary lymph nodes that do not meet CT criteria for
pathologic enlargement.  There are coronary artery calcifications.  There are
bilateral small layering pleural effusions with associated compressive
atelectasis.  The images of the lungs are limited due to motion.  There
appears to be a patchy, predominantly ground-glass opacity in both lower
lobes, left worse than right.  The aorta appears intact. There is debris in
the trachea.
CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITHOUT AND WITH IV CONTRAST:  There is high-density
material tracking along the course of a dilated left ureter consistent with
hemorrhage that is new compared to the previous study.  New stranding in the
left retroperitoneum is also present consistent with retroperitoneal
hemorrhage.  Perinephric stranding is present, as was seen on the previous
study.  The degree of dilatation of the left ureter is unchanged.  Several
foci of air outside of the collecting system are present, presumably
postprocedural in nature.  Contrast-enhanced images show abnormal perfusion of
the left kidney with a striated appearance, most severe at the upper pole with
peripheral wedge-shaped hypoenhancing areas also present on top of the areas
of reduced perfusion.  No active extravasation of contrast is seen.  The right
kidney is normal.  The liver, spleen, and adrenal glands are unremarkable.
Pancreas is unremarkable with slightly prominent distal common bile duct
measuring up to 8-9 mm.  There is a small cystic lesion measuring 5 mm at the
head of the pancreas (series 10, image 143).  Small and large bowel are
(Over)
[**2143-4-13**] 5:04 PM
CT ABD W&W/O C; CT CHEST W&W/O C                                Clip # [**Clip Number (Radiology) 38350**]
CT PELVIS W&W/O C
Reason: ? PE, evidence of pneumonia
Admitting Diagnosis: SEPSIS
Field of view: 38 Contrast: OPTIRAY Amt: 130
______________________________________________________________________________
FINAL REPORT
(Cont)
grossly unremarkable.  The aorta, celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery,
inferior mesenteric artery, and renal arteries appear patent.
CT OF THE PELVIS WITHOUT AND WITH IV CONTRAST:  The prostate gland is
enlarged.  Thickening of the bladder wall is again demonstrated.  Several foci
of air within the bladder are presumably secondary to the Foley catheter.  The
rectum and sigmoid colon are unremarkable.
BONE WINDOWS:  There are degenerative changes with no suspicious lytic or
sclerotic lesions.
IMPRESSION:
1.  New high-density material surrounding the left ureter and tracking within
the retroperitoneum consistent with hemorrhage.
2.  Abnormal perfusion of the left kidney, most severe at the upper pole.
Findings are consistent with pyelonephritis.  Edema and abnormal perfusion at
the upper pole and interpolar region medially with multiple peripheral
hypoenhancing wedge- shaped regions likely represent ischemia and a component
of infarction.
3.  Limited examination for pulmonary embolism due to suboptimal contrast
bolus with no large central embolus seen.  Evaluation of distal segmental and
subsegmental branches is limited.
4.  Small bilateral layering pleural effusions with associated compressive
atelectasis. Patchy predominantly ground-glass opacities in both lower lobes,
left worse than right could represent pneumonia or pneumonitis.
5.  5mm cystic lesion in the head of the pancreas. Recommend 1 year follow up.
The above was discussed with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 951**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1238**] at approximately 6:30 p.m. on
[**2143-4-13**].
